title: Intravascular extra-digital glomus tumor of the forearm
patient: A 45-year-old female presented with a persistently tender and painful swelling in her left forearm for more than 2 years. The lesion was of a small size (1 × 2 cm size) as shown in Fig. . However, no sensory alteration or temperature hypersensitivity was observed. The patient denied any family history of similar condition or traumatic injury to the forearm. The swelling was excised (Fig. ). Interestingly, a superficial vein was feeding the lesion. Therefore, the feeding vein was cauterized and the lesion was sent for histopathology that confirms the diagnosis of intravascular glomus tumor.
